dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, I was just reading this really interesting piece about, uh, the economy during the pandemic, and there's this weird paradox that jumped out at me.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, so all that government aid, like loans and subsidies?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, so all that government aid, like loans and subsidies?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But the problem is, um, they often did it without really trying to separate the viable businesses from, well, those that didn't have good prospects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so we've ended up with what they call "zombie firms," I bet. Companies that probably *should* have failed but are being propped up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so we've ended up with what they call zombie firms, I bet. Companies that probably should have failed but are being propped up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! And now policymakers are kinda stuck. They can’t just abruptly cut off all that support, obviously.

dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] No, because that would cause a huge wave of bankruptcies, right? And, uh, politically, that would be suicidal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But if they keep supporting all these zombie firms, it's super expensive, fiscally, and it actually hampers new, innovative companies from entering the market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, how do you even tell which is which? Separating the corporate living from the corporate dead, as they say, is tricky.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A

dialogue_turns.text: The employees? But wouldn't they just, like, lie to save their jobs?
